title: CTRL0000087794 - Transcribed Interview of Wandrea Arshaye Moss, (June 1, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held in Room 4480, O'Neill House Office
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
And we'll go on the record now, please.
This is a transcribed interview of Wandrea Shaye Moss,
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol, pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd like to please ask the witness to state your full name and spell
your last name for the record.
And, Counsel, could you please also identify yourself for the record.
Brittany Williams, W-i-1-1-i-a-m-s, from Protect Democracy.
Meryl Governski with Willkie Farr & Gallagher.
So this will be a staff-led interview today.
Mike Gottlieb with Willkie Farr & Gallagher.
As I described a little bit off the record
before we got started, members of the select committee may be joining us, and I'm
pleased that we have a member of our committee on right now.
So, if our members join, they'll do so remotely.
We'll be able to see them on the
participant screen there on the right-hand side.
they join us and also to let the record reflect that they've joined.
course, ask questions when they do join.
We'll also do our best to let you know if
I serve as an investigative counsel on the staff of
the select committee, and I'm joined here in the room today by my colleague,_
who is a professional staff member for the committee.
And, before we get started today, I'd like to go over some ground rules.
described before we got started, these are the same that we cover with all of our
witnesses, so thanks for your patience as I walk through them.
So we have our official reporters here.
suggest any corrections before it's finalized.
They're transcribing the record of the
You and your attorneys will have an opportunity to review the transcript and
And, as you know, this interview today is being videotaped, and the Webex
portion is being recorded, but the official reporter's transcript is going to be the official
So some kind of best practices for these type of interviews:
please wait until each question is finished before you begin your response, and I also will
try not to speak over you, to let you finish your answer before I ask the next question.
That is to be able to create as clean a transcript record as possible.
Our official reporters also cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking or
So we'll ask that you answer with an audible, verbal response.
And, although this is a transcribed interview, it's not under oath.
remind you, as we remind all of our witnesses, that it is unlawful to deliberately provide
So, as we go through our discussion today, it's
important that you understand our questions and are able to answer them to the best of
questions are not clear or if it would be helpful to rephrase the question.
So, to that end, please don't hesitate to ask me to repeat myself if my
And, similarly, if you don't know the answer to a question, please do say you don't
know it, or if you can't recall, then please say that as well.
We do have your attorneys here today too.
So, if there's anything that I ask you
that you have any concerns, you can, of course, take a break to confer with them.
can do that off the record here in the room or if you'd like to take some time back in the
holding room, to have a longer conversation, we can arrange for that too.
And, as we go through the process, I don't think -- we'll try not to keep you overly
long here today, but if you need a break for any other reason, to get up, walk around, or
take a bathroom break, then just let us know.
Any questions before we get started?
Counsel, is there anything you would like to address before we go?
Just one thing I'd like to say.
This is Mike Gottlieb from Willkie
Ms. Moss is here appearing voluntarily today and, like Ms. Freeman yesterday, in
that appearance does not waive nor intend to waive any applicable privileges that may
apply to aspects of her ongoing litigation.
Before we get started, Ms. Moss, I understand you have something
prepared that you'd like to share with us today.
Thank you for inviting me here today.
ArShaye Moss, but some people call me Shaye, and I used to be an election worker.
Almost everything else that people have heard about me is a lie, a lie that has changed
I never imagined that I would be testifying before a congressional committee
because people have spread lies about me and -- my family and me.
I was born in Georgia, and I've lived there my whole life.
I am the third generation in my family to sign up for
When I was growing up, my mom worked for Fulton County.
I knew that I wanted to follow in their footsteps.
made sure Georgia residents were properly registered to vote.
I worked there for more than 10 years.
I loved my job, and I was really good
I even created new procedures to make our process faster and more accurate.
When I was young, my grandmother made sure I knew how important it was to
vote because it's an opportunity that a lot of my family before me did not have.
I wanted to make sure that everyone had that opportunity.
on their own, but older people sometimes needed help.
Younger voters could usually figure out how to register and vote
I remember even driving to a hospital once to help an elderly woman who wanted
My first and only job was working for Fulton County Voter Registration and
Registration forms and ballots aren't just pieces of paper to me.
real people, voters with disabilities, single parents, college students, Active Duty military
I gave everyone my card so they have an actual person that they can contact
I wanted them to know I valued their vote just as much as they
My mom taught me that you do things the right way, not the easy way.
checking, double checking, focusing on the details, and on a tight deadline.
I was used to quietly doing my job, even if that meant waking up way too early,
I missed so many of my son's activities because I had to work.
Whenever I missed something, I knew how lucky I was that my grandmother could fill in
I wanted to show my son that hard work would pay off.
Ever since December 2020, my family has been under attack for doing my job.
See, my mother Ruby signed up to work with me in 2020
In the 2 weeks before the election, we worked from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., 7 days a
were so proud of a job well done, and my mom was proud of me.
During election week, we worked even longer shifts.
But, in early December, former President Trump, Rudy Giuliani, and their allies
start spreading terrible lies about my mother and me.
the State Farm Arena in a suitcase.
They said we snuck ballots into
They said we lied about a water main break to kick observers out.
They said we counted ballots multiple times to try to steal an election.
And they said we passed around a flash drive to try to hack a machine.
The thing they got so excited about, that my mom passed to me, was a ginger
None of the lies are true.
Why do I say it doesn't make sense?
You can't just walk a suitcase full of fake
ballots into a counting facility in Fulton County.
We have a system in place to make sure
Information on the envelope has to match the information from the real voters.
Information from the precincts has to match the total votes counted.
invent large numbers of votes or voters, especially in the system with hand recounts,
cameras everywhere, campaign officials, State election officials monitoring your every
reasons, you can't just count ballots multiple times.
The discrepancy will show up in the
I helped count ballots in 2016 when President Trump won and 2018
I was proud of our work in those elections.
lost because I'm not a political person.
It didn't matter to me who won or
The job was never about politics to me.
allies just didn't like the outcome of the election.
So they attacked us simply because
As a result, I've been threatened and harassed.
Former President Trump, Rudy Giuliani, and their
But you can't say to people, like, you can't say much to people that think up
And, as for the water leak, it was a real thing that happened with dozens of
One stranger told me I was lucky
Another one told me that I should hang alongside my mom for
My son received some of those threats -- a child -- he heard horrible things about
his mom just because I did my job.
People showed up at my grandmother's home trying to bust the door down and
conduct a citizen's arrest of my mom and me.
People would email the general email address for our office, so everyone could see the
threats and hateful messages directed to me.
These were people who didn't even know us.
They just refused to accept the outcome of the election.
I have to live with this every single day.
The threats followed me to work.
Before 2020, I was never scared of
people knowing my name, but after, I stopped giving out my business cards to voters.
Now I worry when I'm in the grocery store.
mom and she calls my name out across the aisle.
a voice I don't recognize says my name.
I worry when I go shopping with my
I worry when I pick up the phone and
I feel responsible for what happened to my family, like, somehow it's all my fault
because I chose to work as an election worker.
I wanted to help, but I never imagined it
Like, can you imagine what it's like to feel responsible for your grandmother, your
mother, your teenage son being threatened and lied about over and over again, to be
singled out as a criminal, to be accused of treason in the only country you've ever called
I didn't realize how much I loved my job until it was taken away from me by a few
people who decided that their lie is more important than my life.
But I'm here, I'm here today for more than myself and my family.
speak for the election workers out there who were, are, or will be threatened and
attacked for just doing their jobs.
I'm here today because I want the truth to be heard.
through what I've been through, especially not our election workers who do the heavy
They don't receive the recognition or respect for the service that they provide this
Vet they showed up, I showed up, every single day, every single election.
never missed one election in 10 years.
I'm here because this has to stop.
The people responsible for the lies need to be
election workers and protect the victims of disinformation, like my family and me.
doesn't, I know there will be many more just like me.
Because of the lies, my son has to grow up way too quickly.
there are some days I don't want to get out of bed.
up under the covers and disappear.
be again able to do the work that I felt called to do.
There are some days I want to curl
Because of the lies, I've lost who I was, and I'll never
My life will never be the same.
I had to just come to terms with the fact that there will always be people who
There will always be someone that believes I
should be in prison or that I should be dead.
me, and I'm here to tell my truth and to help make sure this never happens to anyone
There's no way to fix what happened to
My loss has got to be for something.
Thank you very much, Ms. Moss.
Take all the time you need.
continue on, that's perfectly fine too.
If you want to take a break before we
Well, first, I just want to thank you for your service as an
election worker throughout the 10 years that you just described to us, and I hope we'll
have an opportunity to learn a little bit more about your work with Fulton County and
But thank you very much for the courage that you have shown since then and the
courage that I know it takes to come here and speak with us.
I regret that I will ask you a bunch of questions following up on it because I'm not
sure I can improve much upon that.
So thank you very much and thanks for being here.
I also just want to note before we get started that, you know, we're going to go
over -- I'd like to go back over some of the facts and get a little bit more of a sense of
what it was like for to you have gone through this.
to think about and talk about.
I know those might be difficult things
We appreciate you doing so here today.
But I also don't want you to have to talk about anything in this context that might
make the trauma that you've gone through any worse.
over a line that you're not comfortable talking about, I hope that you'll let me know and
Mr. Schiff, I see your camera's off -- is there anything you would like to say before
So, if any of my questions do go
I just wanted to take this opportunity to thank you for your incredible
service to the people of Fulton County, the people of Georgia, and around the country.
Thank you for the courage you've demonstrated.
of election workers around the country, all too many others of whom are facing threats as
Thank you for speaking out on behalf
As I mentioned to your mom, I'm very, very alarmed at what you and your family
No one should have to go through that and endure what you have.
I can relate to part of what you've experienced, the threats that I and my family
So your words really resonate with me.
But I want to thank you for coming in today to talk about these events.
as they may be to talk about, it's important that we really bring to the attention of the
American people what's happened in this country and the danger to our democracy.
We need people like yourself who just count the ballots, do what they're
supposed to do, and there's a real danger to that process with what happened to you and
So thank you again for coming in today.
years, and I'm sorry for what you and your family have had to go through as a result.
Thank you for your service over the
So, Ms. Moss, I'd like to start at the beginning a little bit, and my
questions today I think will be organized.
I want to give you a little bit of an overview.
I would love to just talk little bit about your work for Fulton County, how you became
involved, and what your work entailed on previous elections, and then talk a little bit
about the 2020 election, and then how you learned of the lies that were being told about
you and sort of the, you know, factual -- the facts about what happened in December, in
And then, at the end, I would plan to talk with you a little bit more about the
impact on your family, the types of threats that you've received, which I know you've
described to us getting started here, but maybe if we can get a little bit more detail about
that at the end, if you're comfortable.
So I know you've told us that you worked for the Fulton County
Registration and Elections Department, I think you said, for 10 years.
So tell me, how did you first become employed by
the Fulton County Registration and Elections Department?
Well, I first became employed, well, because my mom was working Fulton
County, and she informed me that they were hiring for temps and said:
So I did it; I applied, received an interview, and was hired as a temporary
And, when you were first hired, did you work just around election day, or
were you there for the entirety of the year?
Well, when I was first hired, like, September 25th, 2011, and it was for the
November election that was coming up in 2011.
were released in December, and I was called back in February.
few elections, and they just let me stay on for the whole year basically.
And so we were -- most of the temps
And, by then, I got to know people, learned, like, different people jobs, what they
do, you know, tried to help them with the work so I could learn.
one of the main temps that they're going to call back every year.
And I just always kept that in mind, and, like I said, my grandmother worked for
What type of jobs did you do, either around election day itself
Well, leading up to elections, we're always processing voter registration
applications, whether they are by mail, through the Department of Driver Services,
So, once the deadline comes, now we're processing absentee applications.
So we're just trying to process, because it's a
we all have to go to poll worker training.
And then I was a part of the mail room crew, basically stuffing, and, you know, we
have the machines to stuff the ballots and mail them off.
And that's what I would do,
and receive them back and give, you know, give the voters credit for voting.
was the main job that I was doing.
And then that's the same, like, crew, so to speak, basement crew, that will take
the ballots to whichever location, you know, they want us to take them to and start to
So it's literally been all I've done the entire time.
That's what I was going to ask you.
So what was it about your job, I know
you said in your remarks at the beginning here that you loved the job.
What did you love about it?
Well, I loved that -- you know, it was my first job, and I love that they
don't want to work the hardest way.
I think it's this only child thing, that we
I'd rather work on finding a way to make this
So I was that person for them.
I would, you know, do Excel files and different things to help whatever task we
were doing to make it easier and, you know, become the best at it.
And I just found the love for the ballots.
I like working with the machines.
That's something that you don't do on a normal job.
trained to work on all the machines.
I didn't -- I'm not a sit-at-a-desk-type of girl.
And that's what I like, getting
You know, I could do it, but, yeah.
And I think you said earlier that you had interaction directly
with voters helping them to complete their either registration or the absentee ballot
So tell me about those interactions.
What did you enjoy about interacting
Well, everyone has a desk and you have your own direct number.
always have to have your phone on ready.
know, you pick up the calls.
So, when the calls come in to the office, you
And that's where you help the voters, mainly older people are the ones who are
going to call and get help because now you can do everything on the computer, on your
phone, and, I mean, or cell phone.
They want you to mail them their precinct card:
I want you to put an application
And I know what it's like trying to get through to companies and automated
give them my card so, if they have any questions, they can reach me directly.
So I wanted them to -- I wanted to first help them over the phone and then
And, after doing that for a few years, you have a lot of people that are just, like,
It's that time again, Ms. Moss.
for my son too, he's in college now.
You know, that just became what I do.
And people come to the front desk as well, and, you know, I would treat them the
same way so they would come to the front, say:
And that's what I love, being the one that could make everything okay for them.
They come in upset, and they leave, like, so happy.
And the goal, I think you said this earlier, the goal is helping
them to be able to have their voice, I think you said.
So tell me more about your comments at the beginning, about how those
pieces of paper, what they resembled as far as the voters, the individual voters?
So it's a whole lifeline to
Like, they will call, say an elderly woman will call and say:
I am no longer able to
I will send you an application, and you fill it out, and you mail it
And I'm going to give you a postage -- you know, the postage is paid and
I'm putting everything in the envelope along with my card.
help filling it out, let me know.
So, in the mail room, we're getting everything that comes that day.
get a hundred applications that day, we have to have it on the dashboard for the
secretary of state to see, on this date, we have a hundred applications.
Those applications will get that date put on them, and then, when I put it in the
system to give them a ballot, they keep their date.
When I mail them their ballot, it has
on My Voter Page, that's how you're able to see your election, the day it was issued, the
day it was received, and then the day you got credit.
When it comes back, I have their new date.
And, if they go to their record
So that -- that was our process.
Well, I could tell that you -- I think you described working your way up and
clearly had a very good handle on all of the rules and regulations and it seems took the
administration of the process very seriously.
And tell me -- I mean, to state the obvious, you're helping everyone who
calls in seeking to register for vote, regardless of whether they're Democrat or
We don't identify you by party in Georgia.
just someone who wants an application to be able to vote.
So I think at the beginning you mentioned that you
had participated in several other kind of high-profile elections during your time with
I know you mentioned the 2016 Presidential election as well as the 2018
So tell us about the process for the Presidential election in 2016, and what
was your role in the counting tabulation process that election day?
we train everyone on how to use the machines, and we just get to work.
Well, it was -- basically everything was the same.
I've always did the same thing.
that's mainly what I was doing.
helping, you know, if someone might've needed help.
I -- you know, we first get there,
I was just the one that's hopping around to make sure, you know, if someone had
But, in 2016 and '18, then we were printing the ballots, and
I was stuck at the printer all the time and then just
I had my supervisors, and the
And the 2018 Governor's race was quite close if I
And there was a recount afterwards?
Were you involved in that process as well?
So tell us a little bit about that.
How did the -- I assume -- well, what's the
impact that such a close race and a recount has on you all as election workers?
I mean, it's just part of the job.
it's close and what we have to do.
lot of temps to help out with the process.
It's something that's very common when
So basically for the election, election day, we hire a
But usually when they want a recount, all the temps are gone, and it's just us.
it's interesting for the recount because we're teaching our fellow permanent staff how to
do this, ones that, you know, usually don't this on the regular.
So it's always rewarding to teach someone something new and show them
another part of the process that, you know, they're involved with.
So let's talk a little bit about election day, November 3rd, 2020, this most
So tell us about the election day itself.
you said that being an election worker requires a lot of early mornings and late nights
So what time did you get to the State Farm Arena that
And how did the day go for you?
It was one of our typical election days.
What do you want to know about
It was a long day; you were working hard.
And tell me, just generally, what was your role, what part of the tabulation process were
So, by election day, I'm just overseeing everything.
have any questions on how to use the machinery, or, you know, I'm just overseeing and
I'm signing in the ballots, of course, that are coming from the government center,
Yes, you can take a break.
Just, you know, the typical things helping them, that's about it.
And the process that was going on at the State Farm Arena tabulation center
was specifically counting, tabulating absentee ballots in Fulton County.
How did the number of absentee ballots in the 2020 election
The 2020 election was more than I've ever seen.
election was more than I ever seen.
literally to the ceiling of applications, so the ballots were unbelievable.
It was a lot of absentee, but I can't even -- it was a
And, you know, those applications first, there was just -- we had a room full, like,
The biggest staff I've had, yes.
So how did the rest of the day go?
there counting quite late in the evening.
that you were -- had been involved with before?
Did Fulton County have extra staff hired for this election, for the
Did you perceive it as a normal election day
So when, after election day, did things start changing for you?
When did you perceive that something -- these lies that you've told us about, that we
know about through our investigation, when did they start?
Well, I was at work on December 4th, and the registration chief brought me
into his office, and in his office was the director of registration.
And they told me to sit
down, turned the camera around -- turned their computer around, and clicked a link and
It was a video of my coworkers and myself at State Farm Arena and asked me have
I heard about this or seen about this, you know, have I been getting harassed or threats
or -- and I was in shock.
Said they are all over all my social media.
So, you know, I really don't use anything but lnstagram, and so, on lnstagram, I
had like hundreds and hundreds of people requesting to get into my lnstagram, but at
that time, the chief said they were in his Facebook.
So I went to Facebook, and then I was, like:
No, I haven't heard about any of this.
You haven't been getting any threats?
Oh, how do you see your messages
It's a whole different app called Messenger.
So I went to Messenger, and I just saw a flood of messages.
And I'm not sure if you're aware of how the messages look.
open it, you can just see the first few words of each message.
and I can tell it's not nice, see a lot of the N word, "treason," and, you know, all of these
So I didn't want to get into deep into it while I'm in the office with the director and
Oh, yes, they are all over my social media.
And, you know, they were saying:
And, you know, I was under the impression, like, by the end of the week, this is
going to be, you know, thrown out, like, it doesn't make any sense.
That is when I found out.
They told me to check on my family, and unfortunately
I did, and they were receiving the same things too.
because then I had the chance to look at them and read them and see how much people
I went home and just was crying
All the sacrifices I made to make all this happen every single year, multiple times a
year a lot and -- yeah, I was crying, called my best friend for comfort, and she's, like:
you know, some people called my phone talking about you.
And then my son comes in the room, and it's like I'm just distraught at this point.
And I was showing him, you know, the things.
want -- I'm always upfront with him.
been calling and messaging my phone.
And, at this time, he's 14, I
Oh, that's why those people have
So that's when I -- that's when I first found out, and, you know, I noticed -- well,
Rudy Giuliani is who put out the video.
my name, and that's how they were able to, you know, find me.
video was silent, how do you, you know, know me?
And then, that morning, Gateway Pundit put out
We're wearing masks, and I have these long braids, and, you know, looking tired,
like how -- and that is how -- that's how I found out everything, and it's, like, overnight
I'd like to ask you a couple of followup questions about that if
meeting by the director and the chief.
You mentioned that you were at work and you got pulled into a
And what did the video that they showed you on the computer,
It looked like the video we would see every time we entered or exit the
We knew we were being recorded.
So it was, like, a surveillance video.
It looked like someone took part of the
Did it have the four different views
And so tell me a little bit about that.
You said that you knew that
the process was being recorded, the tabulation process.
election worker, what are the -- how did you know that you were being recorded, and
what were the levels of security and supervision of the process?
Usually it's, like, these guys that set up this
recording, looks like a recording TV little studio.
And we just work around them.
But, since we were in the nice arena where the Hawks play, they had built-in
cameras, you know, in the ceiling.
there's always a recorder there from start to finish, every single day.
So it's always, like, we're always recorded, and
And, during the tabulation process, is it correct that there are members of
the media there and also observers from the political parties that watch what you're
leftover lunches and breakfast and try to, you know, keep them happy and have to stop
But I also have a secretary of state monitor that's always with me, literally.
I want to make sure everything is transparent.
I'm going to the rest room.
And he writes everything down, and he's always with me.
So, when you're in your supervisor's -- or the director and the chief's
office there looking at the video, did you learn where this video had come from?
They told me that it's circulating around on the internet and everywhere,
and people are saying that we're trying to steal an election.
And did they give you a sense for whether they thought that that was true or
Well, we all knew it was false because that's why -- I was, like:
You mentioned that you learned that Rudy Giuliani, the
President's lawyer, had posted or promoted the video.
How did you learn of that?
And then that Gateway Pundit had published your name.
And is that how you think that people started to find you to reach out to you in the ways
Did you ever come to learn that there had been a hearing of the State senate
where this video had been played and Mr. Giuliani, as well as other people, had made
comments about what the video showed?
Do you remember what those were?
Not -- like, I remember -- it wasn't nothing nice, like, we're drug dealers and
I thought in the first time that Mayor Giuliani was at the State senate
hearing, it was on December 3rd, 2020, and he -- there was another Trump campaign
lawyer, a volunteer, who had played this long video, the surveillance video.
And Mr. Giuliani later commented about it during that hearing and said:
you look at what you saw in the video, which to me was a smoking gun -- described it as a
I wonder what you -- when you learned of that, what your reaction was to it?
My reaction to that, it was mainly just like everything else.
disbelief that such a, for lack of a better word, stupid lie is just circulating around and
their supporters and allies are, like, running with it and believing it.
It's hard to describe exactly how you -- I had so many
After you had that meeting with your elections chief and the
director, did there come a time where you had a meeting with law enforcement officers
about the circumstances of this video?
How long after that initial meeting where you learned about the video, when
Mr. Schiff, I see your video on.
Yes, I just wanted to follow up on a couple things.
The Giuliani testimony was on December 3rd.
Like, within a week or two.
Is there something you would like
And, Ms. Moss, did you say what
day it was that you were brought in to your colleagues' office and played a video?
I don't recall whether you mentioned the day that that happened.
And the video that you were shown, was it -- it was footage from the surveillance
So it was the day after Giuliani's testimony.
Was there any audio attached to it, or what exactly was on the video?
No, it didn't have any audio.
It just showed us working that election
night, just the few of us that were left.
And so, when one of your supervisor asked you, have you seen this,
was it just the video, or was he also referring to the social media postings about the
He was asking if I seen this, like, around on social media or
And that's when I was, like:
